keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz, Bolivia’s first conservative president in 20 years, won a decisive 54.5% of the vote in a runoff election, signaling a dramatic shift from decades of leftist rule.
Paz pledged to rebuild relations with the United States, reversing decades of government antipathy, and emphasized foreign investment and fuel security as key priorities.
The new government plans to eliminate broad fuel subsidies by targeting poor families with direct cash transfers, preserving fuel prices for transport workers.
Paz rejected an IMF bailout, citing public resentment against international financial organizations under previous socialist governments.
He is working on a $3.5 billion loan and another $600 million to balance the national budget within 60 days of taking office.
Paz’s campaign featured a populist running mate, Edman Lara, a former police captain who gained fame on TikTok for anti-corruption videos.
The new administration faces challenges from Indigenous communities and political factions, especially regarding proposed constitutional changes that could affect political representation.
Despite promises of reform, protests erupted in La Paz and Santa Cruz against the election results, citing past electoral fraud and distrust in Bolivia’s democratic institutions.
Paz affirmed a commitment to maintaining Indigenous political representation, while aiming to reform the judiciary to reduce political influence.
The shift in Bolivia’s politics reflects broader regional realignments, especially in Latin America’s shift toward conservative and pro-Western policies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, Bolivia’s first conservative president in 20 years, won a decisive 54.5% of the vote in a runoff election, ending decades of leftist rule under Evo Morales. In a major shift, Paz pledged to rebuild diplomatic ties with the United States, reversing years of hostility and signaling openness to foreign investment and fuel imports. He rejected an IMF bailout, citing public resentment, and plans to restructure fuel subsidies by targeting poor families with cash transfers while maintaining fuel prices for transport workers. His campaign, energized by populist running mate Edman Lara—a former police captain who gained fame on TikTok—successfully appealed to rural and working-class voters. Despite promises of reform, the new administration faces strong opposition from Indigenous communities and political factions, especially over proposed constitutional changes that could undermine political representation. Protests erupted in La Paz and Santa Cruz, fueled by past electoral frauds and distrust in democratic institutions. Paz’s inauguration on November 8 marks a pivotal moment in Bolivia’s political evolution, reflecting broader regional shifts toward conservative, pro-Western governance.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Presidential Runoff, Becoming Bolivia’s First Conservative Leader in Decades
